title: Exploratory Analysis
text:
1 Preliminary Data Exploration
Basic insight into the data.
Let’s visualize the data.
There’s a couple of noteworthy things here:

Most of our variables are continuous
Very few columns have completely missing data
Every row is missing some response, this is expected since we have deidentified some data.
Most concerning is that >50% of our data has missing responses. This creates a huge issue for our data analysis and mischievous detection.

Let’s look into our missing values more


Show the code
# plot_missing(org_data)


Because we have over 350 variables, we may be unable to read every variable. This graph does however show us that missing data is quite troublesome.

title: SGI+ Project Data
text:
This is the home page detailing the purpose and contents of the website.
This website features:

Guide to Identifying mischievous responders.

title: Mischievous Responders
text:
To identify and remove problematic responders, we will employ a rubric to classify all respondents into Extremely High, High, Moderate, and Low risk of problematic responses.
The rubric is as follows:









Tier 4: Removal
Tier 3: High Risk
Tier 2: Moderate Risk
Tier 1: Low Risk




1 EH
2+ Highs
1 High + 1-2 Meds
All else



1 High + 3 Meds
3 Meds + 1 Low




4 Meds





Three datasets will be created from these classifications: SGIP3_data.sav, SGIP2_data.sav, SGIP1_data. Any responses categorized as Extremely High will be removed from all responses.
We will be using the following four criterias for the rubric: Time to complete, Longstring value, IRV value, Attention, and Text response when applicable.

title: Mischievous Responders
text:
3.1 Results


Show the code
# Assign Classification
data <- data %>%
  mutate(DurClass = case_when(
    Duration <= 15 ~ "Extremely High Risk",
    Duration >= 16 & Duration <= 30 ~ "High Risk",
    Duration >= 31 & Duration <= 45 ~ "Moderate Risk",
    Duration > 45 ~ "Low Risk",
    TRUE ~ NA_character_  # For cases that don't fit any criteria
  ))




Show the code
nice_table(table(data$DurClass))


Var1FreqExtremely High Risk742High Risk397Low Risk656Moderate Risk382








Warning



Our findings show that 742 respondents completed the survey under 15 minutes. These responders will be automatically removed from the dataset, and will not be retained.

title: Mischievous Responders
text:
3.2 Removal


Show the code
data <- data %>%
  filter(DurClass != "Extremely High Risk")
nice_table(table(data$DurClass))


Var1FreqHigh Risk397Low Risk656Moderate Risk382


We can confirm that now Extremely High Risk were removed from the data. We have a total of 1435 respondents retained as of now.

title: Mischievous Responders
text:
4.1 Results


Show the code
nice_table(table(data$LongClass))


Var1FreqExtremely High Risk3High Risk17Low Risk1,281Moderate Risk134


Our results show that only 3 respondents were classified as Extremely High Risk. These respondents will be removed automatically.

title: Mischievous Responders
text:
4.2 Removal


Show the code
data <- data %>%
  filter(LongClass != "Extremely High Risk")
nice_table(table(data$DurClass))


Var1FreqHigh Risk395Low Risk655Moderate Risk382


We have a total of 1432 respondents retained as of now.

title: Mischievous Responders
text:
5.1 Beginning Measure: Sexual Identity


Show the code
# Create Subset with Sexual Identity Scales
irv_si <- data[, 78:99]
# Calculate IRV
data$irv_si <- careless::irv(irv_si)

boxplot(data$irv_si, main = "Boxplot of Sexual Identity Scales IRV")











Show the code
# Frequency of irv
table_irv <- table(data$irv_si)
table_irv <- data.frame('IRV'=as.numeric(names(table_irv)), 'Count'=as.integer(table_irv))
table_irv$IRV <- round(table_irv$IRV, digits = 2)
DT::datatable(table_irv)






Our interactive table shows us that 4 individuals straightlined on the Attitudinal measure. Let us now assign classification.


Show the code
data <- data %>%
  mutate(irv_si_class = case_when(
    irv_si == 0 ~ "Straight-lining",
    irv_si > 0 ~ "Reasonable",
    TRUE ~ NA_character_  # For cases that don't fit any criteria
  ))



5.1.1 Results


Show the code
nice_table(table(data$irv_si_class), title = "Frequency of Classification")


Frequency of ClassificationVar1FreqReasonable1,389Straight-lining4

title: Mischievous Responders
text:
5.2 Middle Measure: Attitudinal Scales


Show the code
# Create Subset with Attitudinal Scales
att_irv <- data[, 118:140]
# Calculate IRV
data$irv_att <- careless::irv(att_irv)

boxplot(data$irv_att, main = "Boxplot of Attitudinal Scales IRV")















Note



Our boxplot shows that most respondents report some variable in their response, yet still some have very low IRVs. Let’s taker a closer look.




Show the code
# Frequency of irv
table_irv <- table(data$irv_att)
table_irv <- data.frame('IRV'=as.numeric(names(table_irv)), 'Count'=as.integer(table_irv))
table_irv$IRV <- round(table_irv$IRV, digits = 2)
DT::datatable(table_irv)






Our interactive table shows us that 4 individuals straightlined on the Attitudinal measure. Let us now assign classification.


Show the code
data <- data %>%
  mutate(irv_att_class = case_when(
    irv_att == 0 ~ "Straight-lining",
    irv_att > 0 ~ "Reasonable",
    TRUE ~ NA_character_  # For cases that don't fit any criteria
  ))



5.2.1 Results


Show the code
nice_table(table(data$irv_att_class), title = "Frequency of Classification")


Frequency of ClassificationVar1FreqReasonable1,374Straight-lining4

title: Mischievous Responders
text:
5.3 End Measure: Spiritual Abuse Questionnaire


Show the code
# Create Subset with Attitudinal Scales
irv_saq <- data[, 362:380]
# Calculate IRV
data$irv_saq <- careless::irv(irv_saq)

boxplot(data$irv_saq, main = "Boxplot of Spiritual Abuse Questionnaire Scale IRV")









Our boxplot here shows that there are several individuals who straight-lined, as well as those who have abnormally high IRV. Let’s take a look.


Show the code
# Frequency of irv
table_irv <- table(data$irv_saq) # Change here!!!
table_irv <- data.frame('IRV'=as.numeric(names(table_irv)), 'Count'=as.integer(table_irv))
table_irv$IRV <- round(table_irv$IRV, digits = 2)
DT::datatable(table_irv)






The table shows that there are 21 individuals whom straight-lined on this measure and two who scored above the 75th quartile. Let’s apply the criteria.


Show the code
# Calculating quartiles
lower_quartile <- quantile(data$irv_saq, probs = 0.25, na.rm = TRUE)
upper_quartile <- quantile(data$irv_saq, probs = 0.75, na.rm = TRUE)
high_quartile <- quantile(data$irv_saq, probs = 0.90, na.rm = TRUE)

# Adding a classification based on quartiles
data <- data %>%
  mutate(irv_saq_class = case_when(
    irv_saq == 0 ~ "Straight-lining",
    irv_saq <= lower_quartile ~ "Reasonable",
    irv_saq > lower_quartile & irv_saq < high_quartile ~ "Reasonable",
    irv_saq >= high_quartile ~ "Random Response",
    TRUE ~ NA_character_  # For cases that don't fit any criteria
  ))



5.3.1 Results


Show the code
nice_table(table(data$irv_saq_class))


Var1FreqRandom Response115Reasonable991Straight-lining18

title: Mischievous Responders
text:
5.4 Results for All Three IRVs


Show the code
data <- data %>%
  mutate(IRVClass = case_when(
    irv_saq_class == "Straight-lining" & irv_att_class == "Straight-lining" & irv_si_class == "Straight-lining" ~ "High Risk",
    (irv_saq_class == "Straight-lining") + (irv_att_class == "Straight-lining") + (irv_si_class == "Straight-lining") == 2 ~ "Moderate Risk",
    (irv_saq_class == "Straight-lining") + (irv_att_class == "Straight-lining") + (irv_si_class == "Straight-lining") == 1 ~ "Moderate Risk",
    TRUE ~ "Low Risk"
  ))
nice_table(table(data$IRVClass))


Var1FreqLow Risk1,408Moderate Risk24


Our results show that no respondent was classified as High Risk.

title: Mischievous Responders
text:
9.1 Tier 1: Low Risk Data


Show the code
tier_1_data <- data %>%
  filter(Tier == "Tier 1: Low Risk")

write_sav(tier_1_data, "SGIP_t1_data.sav")

title: Mischievous Responders
text:
9.2 Tier 2: Moderate Risk Data


Show the code
tier_2_data <- data %>%
  filter(Tier == "Tier 1: Low Risk" | Tier == "Tier 2: Moderate Risk")

write_sav(tier_2_data, "SGIP_t2_data.sav")

title: Mischievous Responders
text:
9.3 Tier 3: High Risk Data


Show the code
tier_3_data <- data

write_sav(tier_3_data, "SGIP_t3_data.sav")
